review.title: Refinement Modal Logic
review.abstract: In this paper we present refinement modal logic. A refinement is like a bisimulation, except that from the three relational requirements only 'atoms' and 'back' need to be satisfied. Our logic contains a new operator 'forall' in additional to the standard modalities 'Box' for each agent. The operator 'forall' acts as a quantifier over the set of all refinements of a given model. We call it the refinement operator. As a variation on a bisimulation quantifier, it can be seen as a refinement quantifier over a variable not occurring in the formula bound by the operator. The logic combines the simplicity of multi-agent modal logic with some powers of monadic second order quantification. We present a sound and complete axiomatization of multiagent refinement modal logic. We also present an extension of the logic to the modal mu-calculus, and an axiomatization for the single-agent version of this logic. Examples and applications are also discussed: to software verification and design (the set of agents can also be seen as a set of actions), and to dynamic epistemic logic. We further give detailed results on the complexity of satisfiability, and on succinctness.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The semantics of modal logic uses the concept of "possible worlds" between which an actor cannot distinguish. Therefore, in dynamic systems, actors can acquire new knowledge (e.g. through an announcement or the execution of an action) that enables agents to distinguish between worlds that they could not previously distinguish from each other. From the actor's perspective, what "possible worlds" are has become unimaginable. Thus, a future informative event can be modelled by reducing the accessibility relationship of the actor. [55] In future event logic, the multiagent logic of knowledge is replaced by an operation that stands for "all informative events." sections.heading: 3.5 Modal specifications refinement
sections.text: Modal specifications are classic, practical and expressive mathematical objects that represent the interfaces of component-based systems [36, 44, 45, 46, 4, 49]. Modal specifications are deterministic automatons equipped with transitions of two types: can and must. However, the components implementing such interfaces are deterministic automatons; an alternative language-based semantics can therefore be considered, as shown in [44, 45]. Informally, in each component implementing the modal specification, a transition process is not available. Modal specifications are interpreted as logical specifications that coincide with the conjunctive Kong calculation fragment of the µ calculus [20]. In order to be able to abstract from a particular implementation, a whole theory of modal specifications has been developed that relies on a refinement pre-ordination known as modal refinement. [20] Although their definitions are close to our definition, there may be other means of refinement than the two.

sections.heading: 4 Refinement modal logic
sections.text: In this section, we present modal refinement logic, in which we add a modal operator, which we call a refinement quantifier, to the language of multi-agent modal logic or the language of modal µ-calculation. In previous publications [55, 56], modal refinement logic is referred to as "future event logic." In this interpretation, various 2a operators stand for different epistemic operators (each of which describes what an agent knows), and modal refinement logic can then express which informative events are consistent with a given information state. Here, however, we take a more general position. We list some relevant validations and semantic properties, and also apply logic to known logical frameworks such as the quantified modal logic of bisimulation (by means of relativization) and dynamic epistemic logic.

4.4 Alternating refinement relations
sections.text: Alternative Transitional Systems (ATS) were introduced [3] to model multi-agent systems in which, at each turn of the game between the agents of an ATS, the choice of an agent in one state is a series of states and the successor state is determined by taking into account the intersection of decisions made by all agents. An idea of a-alternating refinement was introduced to reflect a sophisticated behavior of the agent while keeping the behavior of the others intact. Restricted to turn-based ATS, where only one actor plays simultaneously (simultaneous movements are also allowed in the full environment), an a-alternating refinement amounts to demanding "for all b," as we do, but "back" only for the agent a. Consequently, a-refinement is a special a-alternating refinement, which represents a particular a-alternating refinement.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and perspectives
sections.text: Conclusions We conclude that we hope to have established a platform for structural refinement in various modal logic. We established the results on axiomatization, complexity, expressivity, and we gave applications on software verification and design, and on dynamic epistemic logic. We established the relationship to bisimulation quantified logic: refinement refinement followed by relativization. The multi-agent refinement modal logic and the broadest generalization in the form of refinement calculus are only the beginning. One could think of refinement CTL, refinement PDL, (still other) refinement epistemic logic and refinement with further structural limitations, and so on generalization. Each of this logic can think of different axiomnifications and complexity.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper we present refinement modal logic. A refinement is like a bisimulation, except that from the three relational requirements only ‘atoms’ and ‘back’ need to be satisfied. Our logic contains a new operator ∀ in addition to the standard modalities 2 for each agent. The operator ∀ acts as a quantifier over the set of all refinements of a given model. As a variation on a bisimulation quantifier, this refinement operator or refinement quantifier ∀ can be seen as quantifying over a variable not occurring in the formula bound by it. The logic combines the simplicity of multi-agent modal logic with some powers of monadic second-order quantification. We present a sound and complete axiomatization of multi-agent refinement modal logic. We also present an extension of the logic to the modal μ-calculus, and an axiomatization for the single-agent version of this logic. Examples and applications are also discussed: to software verification and design (the set of agents can also be seen as a set of actions), and to dynamic epistemic logic. We further give detailed results on the complexity of satisfiability, and on succinctness.
